## Introduction: Amache Becomes a US National Park

The **Granada Relocation Center**, known as Camp Amache, will become the **Amache National Historic Site**. This is a major step forward in preserving this place, which represents an important turning point in American history.

## Amache National Historic Site Act

US President Joe Biden signed the **Amache National Historic Site Act**. This law will allow the site to become part of the national park system. This means that **Amache's** importance is officially recognized and must be protected.

*   This law will allow the site to become part of the national park system.

The **Amache National Historic Site Act** secures the future of this historic site and ensures that future generations learn about this important history.

## Amache Preservation Society

The organization overseeing the area. The **Amache Preservation Society** plays an important role in preserving and promoting this historic site.

*   Founded by Grenada High School principal John Hopper.
*   Composed of volunteer students who educate people about Japanese internment camps.

The **Amache Preservation Society** was founded by John Hopper, principal of **Grenada** High School, and consists of volunteer students who work to raise awareness about Japanese internment camps. The dedicated work of these students ensures that **Amache's** history remains alive.

## History of Camp Amache

Background information about the operation and timeline of the camp. **Camp Amache** was a concentration camp where Japanese-Americans were forcibly relocated during World War II. This camp represents a dark period in American history.

*   Construction began in June 1942 and opened on August 27, 1942.
*   It covered one square mile with 29 **blocks** of barracks, each with six apartments.
*   The apartments had a coal-burning stove, army bunks, and a light bulb.
*   In 1943, the camp housed more than 7,318 Japanese-Americans.
*   It was officially closed on October 15, 1945.
*   Added to the National Register of Historic Places on May 18, 1994.
*   Designated as a National Historic Landmark on February 10, 2005.
*   President Franklin D. Roosevelt ordered the relocation of more than 120,000 Japanese-Americans after the bombing of Pearl Harbor.
*   The War Relocation Authority built 10 confinement camps in Arkansas, Arizona, California, **Colorado**, Idaho, Utah, and Wyoming.

This means that **Amache** will become a nationally recognized and protected site.

**अमाचे राष्ट्रीय ऐतिहासिक स्थल अधिनियम** इस ऐतिहासिक स्थान के भविष्य को सुरक्षित करता है और यह सुनिश्चित करता है कि आने वाली पीढ़ी इस महत्वपूर्ण इतिहास को सीखे।
